results.title: Stencil art
results.brief_description: This DV Public Imaging work explores the graphic street art of stencil painting. This predominantly political form of street communication and resistance has risen in visibility in recent years. Using the streets of Melbourne as the visual basis for this work, the viewer will be afforded the vision of the different visual and textual styles, edited into a work that is, at times, abstract and, at others, forcefully potent in its political delivery.

results.title: Stella does tricks
results.creator_credit: Compulsive Films, Sidewalk Productions, BFI, Channel Four Television, Adam Barker and Coky Giedroyc
results.brief_description: Having escaped Glasgow and the sexual abuse of the father she once adored, Stella winds up on the streets of London as a teenage prostitute with a vicious middle-aged pimp. Despite her bleak and seemingly hopeless circumstances, a streak of anger and yearning drives her to escape the sadistic men who dominate her life, but not before her pimp exacts one last act of savage abuse. The film shifts abruptly between Stella’s romanticised interior world of memories and fantasies, and the real world where her rage erupts into acts of vandalism and often poetic revenge on the men who have mistreated her. Giedroyc draws on her former experience as a director of realist drama and documentary for British television, handling the often confronting subject matter frankly and suffusing the film with a sense of outrage and urgency. Cast includes Kelly Macdonald, James Bolam, Hans Matheson and Ewan Stewart.

results.title: Stella Dallas
results.creator_credit: Samuel Goldwyn Co, Samuel Goldwyn and King Vidor
results.brief_description: Barbara Stanwyck gives one of her best performances as a social-climbing mother from the wrong side of the tracks. Born a mill-hand’s daughter with no social graces, an ill-fated marriage leaves Stella single-handedly raising her daughter Laurel (Anne Shirley). Stella dreams of a new life for her daughter until she realises that what stands between Laurel and her dreams is Stella herself. This is a memorable and heartbreaking tale of a mother’s love and ultimate sacrifice - with one of Hollywood’s greatest finales. Don’t watch this film without a box of tissues. Also stars John Boles, Barbara O’Neil and Alan Hale. Based upon the novel by Olive Higgins Prouty.

results.title: Stella
results.brief_description: Melina Mercouri’s dynamic performance in “Stella” made her the first internationally renowned Greek film star. The film itself launched the career of Michael Cacoyannis as a director and also led to attention being drawn to the fledgling Greek post-World War II cinema. Mercouri is an Athens night club singer who refuses to behave by the harsh conventional moral standards of Greek society. She has a student lover (Alekos Alexandrakis) and is happy to spend her life singing, falling in love and breaking men’s hearts. She begins an affair with a local football champion, Mitsos (George Foundas), but finds that he refuses to grant her the freedom she has worked so hard to gain. When she decides to leave Mitsos, she finds that her transgression of feminine propriety leads to danger and violence. This beautifully photographed melodrama is a unique representation of both independent female desire and of defiance of misogynist tradition (themes that would resurface in Cacoyannis’ most famous film, “Zorba the Greek”). For a contemporary audience “Stella” is illuminating for its locations amongst the war-torn working-class locales of Piraeus, as well as for its atypical feminist heroine. The original music score by Manos Hadjidakis, combining rembetika and demotic music, is justifiably one of his most famous works. But it is Mercouri who is the unforgettable centre of this stark and powerful film. For the rest of her life, she would be living in Stella’s shadow. In Greek with English subtitles.

results.title: Stelarc: an interview at the N.T.U. Fine Arts Department, Darwin, Australia
results.creator_credit: Northern Territory University and Mary Jane Overall
results.brief_description: Stelarc is a unique performance artist, internationally renown for “events” he stages. In these, he suspends his nude body with fish hooks in various situations or uses a bionic arm and helmet which give him laser eyes. These live works of art, with the use of technology are shockingly magnificent in their audacity and innovation. This in-depth interview conducted in 1991, features footage and photographs from the various Stelarc “events”, and reveals the reasons and ideas behind them. Stelarc’s curiousity and vision have enabled him to make some unusual predicitions about the future of human kind.

results.title: Steffan the violin maker
results.creator_credit: Coronet Films, Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and Paul Saltzman
results.brief_description: Shows the painstaking process of violin making by focussing on sixteen year old Steffan Kellar, an apprentice violin maker and violinist living in West Germany. Highlights the beauty of the violin as a musical instrument, as well as indicating its cultural heritage.

results.title: Steer 270
results.creator_credit: Australia. Navy Office. Directorate of Public Relations, Brian Voce and Vincent Donovan
results.brief_description: Follows a task force made up of the ships Perth, Derwent and Supply, of the Royal Australian Navy on a good will cruise of Mauritius Island, Mombasa, Karachi, Singapore, and Sydney.

results.title: Steelworker
results.creator_credit: Australian National Film Board, Maslyn Williams and Hugh McInnes
results.brief_description: a steelworker relates his impression of life centred around the blast furnace of the Port Kembla district. He recalls the processes involved in steel making, mentions the number of ‘new’ Australians employed at the works, and tells of the facilities for recreation, entertainment and modern living provided by the principal city of the are, Wollongong.

results.title: Steel: A Glimpse of BHP's Newcastle steel works
results.brief_description: A brief look at the BHP steel plant in Newcastle. The film looks first at the smelting process and then concentrates on the rolling and cutting of steel into different shapes.

results.title: Steel saga
results.creator_credit: Broken Hill Proprietary Company and Neville Bletcher
results.brief_description: Studies the growth and development of Port Kembla to 1960. Shows all phases of the production of steel and looks at the lives and activities of the workers who produce the steel. Narrated by David Low, Brian Henderson, Wynne Nelson.
